Award.AwardTitle: Conference Funding Proposal: Advances in Cryptology - CRYPTO 2015

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal supports 20 students for their travel to attend the 2015 Annual International Cryptology Conference (CRYPTO), sponsored by IACR (International Association of Cryptologic Research), in cooperation with the Computer Science Department of the University of California, Santa Barbara. CRYPTO is a highly selective conference in cryptography, attracting students, researchers and industry specialists from all over the world. The scope of research papers accepted to CRYPTO range from the theoretical foundations of cryptology to application and implementation of cryptographic schemes. As such, it fits closely with the goals of NSF's Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program, which include applied cryptography and implementation of cryptographic schemes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advances in Cryptology -- Crypto is a premier venue for the latest academic research in cryptography and is located each summer at the University of California, Santa Barbara. It is organized by the International Association of Cryptologic Research, the main professional organization for cryptography research. Crypto is one of three "flagship" IACR conferences whose purpose is to provide a forum for presentation and discussion of the latest research results.


This grant helped enabled domestic students to attend the conference.  Attendance at top-tier conferences such as Crypto is crucial for the training and development of students. They benefit not only by giving or attending talks, but also from the many opportunities to meet junior and senior researchers, discuss their work, and spark new collaborations to solve the many challenging open problems in the field of cryptography.  The availability of funding support was advertised widely, and generous sponsorship by NSF and industry allowed us to extend some form of support for all students who requested it. In total, 15 students received support from the NSF for attendance in the form of air travel reimbursements, lodging, and registration fees being covered.


This year was the 35th year of the Crypto conference, and we had over 316 attendees with 29 countries represented.
